Comment: It sounds like you had a good opportunity to really explain to that kid why it was bad. If you ever find yourself in that situation again, be patient and explain it fully. Use an analogy to make it relatable. He might not understand why racism is unacceptable if it's super prevalent at home, so talk about how it feels to be bullied by people just because of where you were born or the color of your eyes. It's something you can't control and that doesn't define you, let alone is something that should be used against you   It won't change anything immediately, but maybe it might resonate and stick somewhere in there. And one day...maybe it'll break through. Just telling kids no isn't enough, especially if they don't understand why and it sounds like you are in a unique position to possibly do something cool about that. And imagine how pissed she'd be if one of her kids ends up being a decent human being ü§™

Author: SatoriFound70

Comment: While China produces a ton of consumer goods, the US produces a ton of commercial/industrial/scientific goods.  Chinese labor is broadly low skill/low cost, while US labor is broadly the opposite, highly skilled and expensive.  The average consumer just wants stuff that's cheap and mostly works, but if you need high quality tooling, custom scientific equipment, very tightly toleranced parts, etc, you get it from a US manufacturer.  In addition to global feelings toward the US souring, the tariffs also increase the cost of US goods for other countries which will inevitably open doors for Chinese and European finished goods manufacturers to fill that vacuum.  We think of Chinese goods as being cheap junk because we buy a lot of cheap junk, but they have access to high cost skilled labor just like we do, they just haven't had the opportunity to build that industry like we have.  I'd you're buying high end finished goods requiring skilled labor to produce, but now the US also has +~25% material costs for all our goods so there's a massive opportunity for other nations to fill that gap
Author: ExcitingAmount

Comment: With Trump first term he had tariff and sanctions on China. The way China got around them is if they imported raw materials to a country, say wood to Mexico, then build something in that country from the raw materials like a desk. That desk would then be considered a product made and exported from Mexico. This is literally how Mexico became the USA #1 trade partner. By trading goods made in factories that China built, and owned part of, in Mexico. It‚Äôs not just Mexico. Look up BRICS, or the port of Chancay.  https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Port_of_Chancay

Comment: This is how it works with many ‚ÄúMade in America‚Äù companies. Take for instance Hubbardton Forge based in Castleton, VT still says ‚ÄúMade in America‚Äù. (It used to be 35 years ago.). Now most pieces are made, arc welded and shipped back in pieces for final assembly. Years ago a perspective BIL was one of their engineers. They had a big full body mirror in the product line at the time. The entire mirror was made in China. When it arrived back to the states the frame was assembled and glass glued in place. So Tim designed an adhesive because the glass tended to fall out in shipping. After showing this adhesive to his boss. He was fired, all his work on the adhesive was taken. The adhesive is now also made in China. And shipped back here for assembly.
